articles.headline: Microsoft Introduces a Challenger to the iPad
articles.snippet: In its biggest push ever into the hardware business, Microsoft unveiled a tablet computer called Surface that it intends to challenge Apple’s iPad.
articles.abstract: In its biggest push ever into the hardware business, Microsoft unveiled a tablet computer called Surface that it intends to challenge Apple’s iPad.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In its most strategically significant push yet into the hardware business, Microsoft on Monday unveiled a tablet computer called Surface that is intended to challenge Apple’s iPad.

articles.headline: With Risks for Growth Still Hazy, Fed to Weigh New Aid
articles.snippet: Federal Reserve officials will meet to decide whether the economy needs more help amid considerable uncertainty over domestic growth and the impact of Europe’s debt crisis.
articles.abstract: Federal Reserve officials will meet to decide whether the economy needs more help amid considerable uncertainty over domestic growth and the impact of Europe’s debt crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In retrospect, this might not have been the best week for a long-scheduled meeting of the Federal Reserve’s policy-making committee.

articles.headline: Goldman Stuck With a Defense Tab, and Awaiting a Payback
articles.snippet: Goldman Sachs must continue to pay Mr. Gupta’s bills until the case is completely resolved, a process that could take a couple of years.
articles.abstract: Goldman Sachs must continue to pay Mr. Gupta’s bills until the case is completely resolved, a process that could take a couple of years.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Goldman Sachs, the insider trading case against a former board member, Rajat K. Gupta, which ended in a conviction on Friday, was distracting and discomforting.

articles.headline: One Wall Street Seer Says the Greek Tragedy Is Near
articles.snippet: Mark Grant doesn’t call his assumptions Doomsday, but reality: Greece will most likely fall apart in the next four months unless “there is debt forgiveness or Europe keeps handing them money like they are a ward of the state.”
articles.abstract: Mark Grant doesn’t call his assumptions Doomsday, but reality: Greece will most likely fall apart in the next four months unless “there is debt forgiveness or Europe keeps handing them money like they are a ward of the state.”
articles.lead_paragraph: If you want to be scared, truly terrified, listen to Mark J. Grant. He might be right.

articles.headline: Investors in Search of Bigger Fix to Euro Crisis
articles.snippet: To defuse the crisis, the debt burdens of Europe’s weaker economies and banks may need to be shared by the entire Continent.
articles.abstract: To defuse the crisis, the debt burdens of Europe’s weaker economies and banks may need to be shared by the entire Continent.
articles.lead_paragraph: The latest relief rally in European financial markets was over almost before it began.

articles.headline: Greek Voting Past, Europe Returns to Fiscal Rescue
articles.snippet: Elections eased fears about Greece’s exit from the euro zone, but attention turned Monday to restoring economic health to Europe with Greece still in it.
articles.abstract: Elections eased fears about Greece’s exit from the euro zone, but attention turned Monday to restoring economic health to Europe with Greece still in it.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — After Greek elections eased fears that the country’s exit from the euro zone was imminent, attention turned Monday to an even bigger challenge: restoring the economic body to health with Greece still in it.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Kulish and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Electronics Retailers Scramble to Adapt to Changing Market
articles.snippet: Sales at physical electronics stores have declined an average of 2.6 percent a year in the last five years, while sales online have risen an average of 14.7 percent a year in that period.
articles.abstract: Sales at physical electronics stores have declined an average of 2.6 percent a year in the last five years, while sales online have risen an average of 14.7 percent a year in that period.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as Best Buy insists it can get out of its current predicament, competitors are circling, as everyone tries to prove one point: that electronics stores can thrive.

articles.headline: American Children, Now Struggling to Adjust to Life in Mexico
articles.snippet: The English-speaking children of Mexicans returning because of deportations, tougher state laws and unemployment struggle to adjust, often going to schools that are not equipped to integrate them.
articles.abstract: The English-speaking children of Mexicans returning because of deportations, tougher state laws and unemployment struggle to adjust, often going to schools that are not equipped to integrate them.
articles.lead_paragraph: IZÚCAR DE MATAMOROS, Mexico — Jeffrey Isidoro sat near the door of his fifth-grade classroom here in central Mexico, staring outside through designer glasses that, like his Nike sneakers and Nike backpack, signaled a life lived almost entirely in the United States. His parents are at home in Mexico. Jeffrey is lost.

articles.headline: Lingering Fears Push Spanish Short-Term Borrowing Costs Up
articles.snippet: A debt sale Tuesday reflects deep market fears about the future of the euro and increases pressure on European leaders to come up with a solution to the crisis.
articles.abstract: A debt sale Tuesday reflects deep market fears about the future of the euro and increases pressure on European leaders to come up with a solution to the crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Spain’s cost of borrowing continued its rise into unsustainable territory Tuesday, reflecting heightened fears that the country would eventually need a bailout that Europe might not be able to afford.
articles.byline: By Stephen Castle and Raphael Minder

articles.headline: Walgreen to Take Stake in Alliance Boots for $6.7 Billion
articles.snippet: The American drug store chain Walgreens has agreed to buy a 45 percent stake in Alliance Boots, the European pharmacy retailer, for $6.7 billion, in a deal that could allow Walgreens to take full control of Alliance Boots by 2015.
articles.abstract: The American drug store chain Walgreens has agreed to buy a 45 percent stake in Alliance Boots, the European pharmacy retailer, for $6.7 billion, in a deal that could allow Walgreens to take full control of Alliance Boots by 2015.
